content: A reversal of fortune Thursday morning left stocks battling losses near midday. A session that opened on an up note saw the Nasdaq dive 1.2% in strong trade before noon. The S&P 500 dropped 0.6%. The Dow Jones industrial average held to a 0.2% loss, as Pfizer (PFE), IBM (IBM) and General Electric (GE) all leaned toward a 1% gain.…

Stocks opened lower Tuesday as the major indexes digested recent gains. The Nasdaq fell 0.5%. On Monday, the tech-heavy index hit its highest levels since Oct. 2, 2000. The S&P 500 continued to cool off from Friday's record high, losing 0.5%. It slightly breached the 1700 level. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.6%. Volume was tracking sharply higher…

In 2003, just after the second in a series of massive spikes in natural gas prices shut down portions of the U.S. power grid and rattled the economy, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan explained that the country's ability to produce natural gas wasn't nearly sufficient to meet its needs. At the time, he was right. But within five years, the…

Stocks seesawed to close flat Monday, digesting gains from the prior four weeks. The Nasdaq eased 0.1% after hitting its highest levels since October 2000. The S&P 500 touched a fresh all-time high, but it also ended down 0.1%. Small caps showed modest strength Monday, as the Russell 2000 mustered a 0.2% gain. Stocks had been up modestly early in…

Stocks continued their assault on fresh highs Thursday as several strong earnings reports propelled the market higher. The Nasdaq finished 17 points from its April 11 intraday high of 3,306.95. Tech stocks outperformed again, with the Nasdaq up 0.6%. The S&P 500 added 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.2% gain. Preliminary data showed NYSE and…

The stock market closed mixed Friday after indexes bounced back from an early slump. The Nasdaq rose 0.2% thanks to strength in biotechs, security software and solar stocks.The S&P; 500 fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.3% drop and closed near session lows.Small caps paced the market: The small-cap Russell 2000 climbed 0.6%. Volume rose on the NYSE and edged lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.After a serious decline the prior day, Friday's price reversals were encouraging. Yet the market remained locked in a long sideways trend.Stocks sank at the open as a better-than-expected jobs report for May triggered a slide in bond prices.Energy stocks rose after OPEC left its output targets unchanged, as expected. Solar shares jumped after China-based JA Solar 's (JASO) chief executive offered to buy the company and take it private.Financials also helped lead the stock market today. Bank of America (BAC) rose more than 2% and closed back near a 24.88 buy point. JPMorgan (JPM) rose 2% and hit a new high. Thinly traded BofI Holdings (BOFI) rose 2% and topped the 97.78 buy point of a long cup-with-handle base.It was a strong day for the IBD 50, with the average component up about 1.3%. Volume was just average or light for most of the 50 stocks, though.

Stocks gave up early gains despite dollar weakness and strong gains in the energy sector. The Nasdaq dipped 0.3%. The Down Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each backed off 0.2%. Trading volume was soft, down 10% on the Nasdaq and 40% lower on the NYSE, vs. trading at the same time Friday. Bank of America (BAC) led the…
Let's talk politics for a few minutes. As in winning the White House after two dismal showings by the Republican Party.
The Chicago Democrat, who still sneaks smokes when no one's looking, is president again in large part thanks to Republican errors.

He has no business occasionally occupying the Oval Office, corroding trust in American institutions, violating all laws of fiscal sanity, talking through his hat, monitoring Americans. He had to spend nearly a billion dollars of other peoples' money last year to get millions fewer votes than he did the first time.

Here's a news flash for Republicans: As Obama whispered to Russia's president last year, 2012 was his last election. He ain't running again. In 2016, Democrats will nominate the tired old face of Hillary Clinton. Start creating an achievement record for that struggle.

Yes, she was a nominee lock in 2008 too. But back in those days she was just a former first lady and ineffective senator. She's added to her resume since then as the most global-galavanting secretary of State in history, largely free of the acrid political rancor Obama was stoking in D.C..

And, more importantly, this time Clinton's opposition will be the even more tired face of Joe Biden, the gaffey guy who publicly admitted in 2008 that she would be a better VP. Barring some major development, nomination lock Hillary.

And Washington Republicans are doing just about everything they possibly can right now to ensure that Bill Clinton, the impeached Philanderer-in-Chief, will become the nation's first First Man. That takes some kind of political skill. And stupidity.
Witness Tuesday's big-news House vote on abortion. A 228-196 'victory' to ban abortions nationally after 20 weeks of pregnancy. Woo-Hoo. High-fives in the cloakroom. We be pure.
Of course, that bill is going nowhere. Everyone knows that. It's like hitting it over the fence in batting practice. The Democrat Senate won't even consider it. Obama promised a veto.
Simply put, that House vote could not possibly mean less. To go on the record? Seriously? Is there one sentient American on either side unaware of decades of Republican opposition to abortion?

No one here doubts the sincerity or morality of its supporters or sponsor, Arizona's five-term Rep. Trent Franks. Family man. Two kids. Epic abortion opponent. In the state legislature, his tie-tack even depicted baby feet.

They say the measure was aimed at preventing another Kermit Gosnell case. But the awful deeds of the Philadelphia late-term abortionist were already illegal. Hence, the prison terms. Another law would somehow fail to not stop it better?
First of all, Americans are sick of a legislator-president.
George W. Bush has a higher approval now than Obama, for pete's sake. Voters had to pick a legislator in 2008. So, they opted for the young, historic one who talked good.

They took a good-faith flier on him. Some may still "like" him, while doubting they can afford him. But no one can endure Obama's 1,611 days in office and more than 120 rounds of golf and be impressed by his chief-executiveness. Which isn't a word but should be.
There's an important place for the slippery legislative mind-set in America's political system. It's called the legislature.

Historically, modern Americans prefer decisive presidents who were governors, generals and vice presidents, in roughly that order. Executive experience doesn't guarantee White House success; ask Jimmy Carter.
But it gives a better shot at election than legislative experience; ask John Kerry, Bob Dole, Gerald Ford, Hubert Humphrey, George McGovern, Al Gore, Walter Mondale, Barry Goldwater.

That's why Hillary agreed to bolster her resume as chief executive of the State Department for her nemesis. That's why Mike Pence and Bobby Jindal quit the House to go govern Indiana and Louisiana, respectively.

Here's what Republicans should do: Stop falling for the Democrats' bait to argue about their issues. Who agrees to play every game on the road? And for Lincoln's sakes stop telling us what you would stop--abortion, gun control, ObamaCare, tax hikes, death tax, immigrant DREAMS, yada-yada.

Instead, start telling us what you would do--to make government more efficient, leaner, smaller, to educate children better, to ensure more efficient healthcare, to protect Social Security and Medicare/aid, to create a safe climate for small business to create jobs, to give taxpayers their money's-worth.
You know, there was a time when immigrants embraced the GOP as welcoming them, their ambitions and their children's votes for generations; ask William McKinley.
Ideological purity itself should not be the conservative goal. Better government is, through the freer-enterprise system, not government dictat.
Clinton will spend the next year seeking distance from Obama. She may even criticize him. Her husband has already started in "private" sessions leaked to media.

For four years Clinton was senior member of Obama's cabinet, a crucial cog in his liberal big government administration. She's from Chicago too. She sat at his right hand, not Biden. Make those links, over and over.

She leaves a treasure trove for opp research gnomes to mine--the undeclared war in Libya and resulting chaos, the policy failures in Egypt and Tunisia, the deadly inaction on Syria, the widening gap with Israel, ineffective sanctions on Iran, the unexplained and deadly security and preparedness failures in Benghazi, those trumped-up talking points, her crony aides' interference in State Department investigations. All will be useful someday.

Meanwhile, Republicans ought to focus on doing a good job where they are, on spiffing up their own house and backyard. So, next year and in 2016 voters are invited to make a proper comparison on actual achievements, not left to fall for the smears and false issues of attack ads.
RELATED:Vlad and Barack on Syria: Brothers in arms (deliveries)
Russia and Syria: The upside-down world of Obama diplomacy
Barack Obama's very long history of scandals--and his escapes

Departure of a successful manager is often a red flag for shareholders. They've got to watch the fund closely for signs of deterioration in performance. For shareholders of $1.4 billion FPA Capital , that process began Jan. 1, 2010. Manager Bob Rodriguez stepped aside after holding the helm for nearly 26 years. Shareholders can probably stop holding their collective breath.…

Occidental Petroleum's  (OXY) proposal to split its U.S. and foreign businesses is pressuring more oil companies to follow suit, as the allure of breakups to create more than $100 billion of market value entices investors. ConocoPhillips (COP), Anadarko Petroleum (APC) and Talisman Energy (TLM) are among those being asked whether the U.S. shale boom has made their global business…
Losses and volume eased near midday as pared losses in select stocks were turned into mild gains after a tough morning.

The Nasdaq trimmed its loss to 1.1%. The S&P 500 eased to a 0.9% loss and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%. Volume eased from early highs, but continued to trade above Thursday's levels, with the Nasdaq up 25% and NYSE volume 20% higher.

The primary influence on the stock market today has been a soft March payrolls report delivered by the Labor Department before the market open. The disappointing report triggered a sell-off both in the U.S. and Europe.
Losses continued to be broad, with more than 80% of S&P 500 stocks and about 90% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD trading lower near midday.
F5 Networks (FFIV) continued to lead decliners on the S&P 500, falling 19% after a weak fiscal second quarter outlook. Juniper Networks (JNPR) was next in line, with a 5% loss.

SolarWinds (SWI) sunk 6% in very busy action, slicing its 50-day moving average. The developer of network management software had pulled back in soft trade since hitting a fresh high in mid-March. Friday's lowest mark undercut its most recent 57.87 flat base buy point by about 6%.
A few IBD 50 list leaders turned around early losses to post moderate gains.
OpenTable (OPEN), Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI) and Oasis Petroleum (OAS) all climbed slightly more than 1%. All three still hold sizable losses for the week.

Domestic oil and natural gas producers were, in general, bucking Friday's market trend. Cabot Oil & Gas (COG), one of the top producers in the eastern Marcellus shale region, jumped 3% in strong trade. The stock remains down about 1% for the week, but is trading near the high end of the week's trading range and about 3% below a 69.08 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

A heads-up for investors who follow the economic calendar — at 3 p.m. ET the Federal Reserve plans to release consumer credit data for February.Losses and volume eased near midday as pared losses in select stocks were turned into mild gains after a tough morning.The Nasdaq trimmed its loss to 1.1%. Where's the fairness from the Fair Share president in only a couple of journalists being threatened over their Obama criticism?

How would you like to be among the growing number of aspiring critics of the Windy City Wonder? You point out his lies. His hypocrisies. His cronyism. His duplicities. His waste. His wanton spending. His phony claims. His arrogance.
And what do you get? Nothing. Nada. Not even a "Go to Hell!" e-mail to wave at cameras to enhance professional standing.

Oh, but along comes big-shot Washington veteran Bob Woodward. He says simply yes, sequester was the evil seed that Obama planted two years ago. And Bam! Woodward gets a senior Obama aide asserting that he will live to "regret" such impudence. And then Woodward gets on all the TV shows to talk about his inside sources and next book, which is always just a few weeks away.

Isn't this the Obama White House that professes such concern for "fairness"? Fair wages. Fair taxes. Fair shots at everything, maybe even skeet. Fairness everywhere, even though life isn't fair. Ask Mitt Romney.

What's fair about 23 million under- or unemployed Americans because the president's ego and Joe Biden's big %$#&)[email protected] mouth won't admit their shovel-ready stimulus plans only stimulated union votes and economic stagnation?

Yet when it comes to threatening journalists for writing negative stories, all the Obama White House does is go after Easterners, those writing wusses within the Beltway who couldn't find their way around Topeka without a White House press bus.
Lanny Davis, the old lawyer for Bill Clinton, who really needed lawyers, says he got similar Obama warnings for critical columns about His Eminence in the Oval Office.

Many have written that the Democrat with the pathetic jump shot invented sequester for his own ends. And now it serves his duplicitous purposes to bash his own idea as a Republican one. He'll probably do it again today after the phony White House "negotiation" with congressional leaders. This meeting was so urgent he's waited 10 weeks since the last one. And 12 hours into sequestration.
So, how come only Bob and Lanny get threats? The rest of us are -- what? -- unworthy of telephone or e-mail beratings.

Obama counts on compliant ones within the inbred D.C. media corps to forget to remind news consumers of the serial promise-breaker. The Guantanamo closing. The green energy boom. The denials about bundlers getting federal subsidies. The deficit-halving. The hilarious 2008 vow to go through the budget line-by-line. His war on coal. A massive healthcare measure that would lower costs, guaranteed, championed by the Smoker-in-Chief and implemented by a Surgeon General out of the WWF. LOL
Remember how Romney caused that poor woman's cancer death?
Remember Obama boasting of record oil production, omitting that it's actually declined on federal lands he oversees and is way, way up on private lands free of Obama's grasp? More borscht.

Obama is a pathological liar and a Chicago Democrat, which is repetitive. But still true. Like the little go-fer who served Obama in the White House and the other House and is now mayor of the nation's most populous Dodge City. Both of them favor new gun controls and both from a city where nearly two citizens per day are blown away.

Obama's problem is that he can't have the boys give the same treatment to his critics in D.C. as back home. You saw what New Jersey's ex-Republican Chris Christie got for his autumn suck-up: Billions in aid. Christie's best Dem opponent decided not to challenge the incumbent.
And last weekend at Obama's annual White House banquet for governors, Christie, who doesn't have buff arms, got plopped right next to Michelle Obama, an honor in some circles.

So, what can Obama do? He can leave a troublemaker off the next State Dinner invite list. Oooh. Wow. That'll sting in the congressional gym. He can order history's newest worst secretary of defense to re-direct some project to another state or congressional district. That's the Washington Way.

Like its weather, the Chicago Way is more in-your-face, direct. Health inspectors, sometimes several at a time, develop a habit of stopping by a business at inconvenient times, muttering the magic word "rats." City permits may get inexplicably delayed.

An establishment owned by an annoying political disobedient finds its garbage cans strangely overlooked by city crews week after week. Maybe the owner's nice car with the city sticker gets keyed within days of the last paint repair job. When clients park near a dissident's law offices, they get parking tickets. Or towed. How can they prove the meter hadn't run out when appearing before a judge who's another loyal cog in the Democrat Machine?

But here's a twist. Now that ex-reporter David Axelrod, Obama's newly-ex-strategist, has joined the Washington media, along with Obama's ex-media mouthpiece Robert Gibbs, do you think that pair of sycophants will get their fair share of angry White House complaints over their commentaries?
We regret to say, No.

Summertime means travel time for many American workers. How businesses keep the lights on while employees vacate:
• Stretch the hours. The top working perk identified by respondents to a survey by staffing service OfficeTeam?
Flexible schedules, at 41%, came in first. Leave-early Fridays ranked second at 28%. Third, at 11%, was a company picnic or potluck. Just 5% preferred a relaxed dress code.
How to deliver what workers crave most — time — and still get the work done? Plan.
"Try to get a longer view on what the holiday cycle looks like," said Brett Good, senior district president at Robert Half International, OfficeTeam's parent company.
And explore solutions, like letting workers vary their schedules or work from remote locations.

• Cover for another. Telecommuting from the beach isn't an option for accounting professionals who deal in sensitive financial data. "They are kind of landlocked in the organization," Good told IBD. In that case, he advises cross-training throughout the year so co-workers can cover for each other during peak months.

• Lighten the mood. "Our business tries to incentivize people to spread out their summer vacations and to take them throughout the year by offering special summer perks," said Deborah Sweeney, CEO of MyCorporation.com, which files legal documents for firms. She makes it cooler to be stuck in the office on hot days by occasionally closing up early, catering in food and paying overtime.

• Ask early. The out-of-school months are dotted with obligations, like driving kids to camp and attending family reunions. How to juggle off-hour needs? "My No. 1 policy is advanced notice and communication," Sweeney said. "If there are already a few people off that day and you're last to ask, it's probably not going to work out."
• Let karma rule. "What comes around goes around, and when you have a good team, they want to give back by helping when others are off," Sweeney said.

• Formalize it. A flex Friday program implemented at software-as-a-service provider IMN (IMN) grants those coveted three-day weekends. Called 80/9, the approach offers a Friday off to account managers who work a minimum of 80 hours the nine days prior to their desired long weekend. The schedule benefits employees and the organization "because it builds in a plan and coverage while offering employees flexibility to enjoy a few long weekends in the summer," said Barrie Brian, IMN human resource director.

• Offer support. Workers who are struggling with summertime demands — at home and in the office — should turn to the corporate employee assistance program. This department, more common at larger employers, helps workers with personal issues. "They often offer employees resources to help them more easily line up summer camp options, day care options and alternate care," Brian said.
"They also offer limited counseling and support to employees who experience extra stress as a result of managing family and work during the long summer vacation."

• Oblige them. "At VAI, many of our team members have extended family in various countries around the world," said CEO Bob Vormittag. "When it comes to vacation, people often take weeks at a time to travel overseas to see family."

How to accommodate? The software firm makes covering for absences a culture cog. "Our team approach here allows them to unplug and truly enjoy their time away," Vormittag said, with full confidence their colleagues are minding the store.Summertime means travel time for many American workers. How businesses keep the lights on while employees vacate:• Stretch the hours. The top working perk identified by respondents to a survey by staffing service OfficeTeam?Flexible schedules, at 41%, came in first. Leave-early Fridays ranked second at 28%. Third, at 11%, was a company picnic or potluck. Just 5% preferred a relaxed dress code.How to deliver what workers crave most — time — and still get the work done? Plan."Try to get a longer view on what the holiday cycle looks like," said Brett Good, senior district president at Robert Half International, OfficeTeam's parent company.And explore solutions, like letting workers vary their schedules or work from remote locations.• Cover for another. Telecommuting from the beach isn't an option for accounting professionals who deal in sensitive financial data. "They are kind of landlocked in the organization," Good told IBD. In that case, he advises cross-training throughout the year so co-workers can cover for each other during peak months.• Lighten the mood. "Our business tries to incentivize people to spread out their summer vacations and to take them throughout the year by offering special summer perks," said Deborah Sweeney, CEO of MyCorporation.com, which files legal documents for firms. She makes it cooler to be stuck in the office on hot days by occasionally closing up early, catering in food and paying overtime.• Ask early. The out-of-school months are dotted with obligations, like driving kids to camp and attending family reunions. How to juggle off-hour needs? "My No. 1 policy is advanced notice and communication," Sweeney said. "If there are already a few people off that day and you're last to ask, it's probably not going to work out."• Let karma rule. "What comes around goes around, and when you have a good team, they want to give back by helping when others are off," Sweeney said.• Formalize it. A flex Friday program implemented at software-as-a-service provider IMN (IMN) grants those coveted three-day weekends. Called 80/9, the approach offers a Friday off to account managers who work a minimum of 80 hours the nine days prior to their desired long weekend. The schedule benefits employees and the organization "because it builds in a plan and coverage while offering employees flexibility to enjoy a few long weekends in the summer," said Barrie Brian, IMN human resource director.• Offer support. Workers who are struggling with summertime demands — at home and in the office — should turn to the corporate employee assistance program. This department, more common at larger employers, helps workers with personal issues. "They often offer employees resources to help them more easily line up summer camp options, day care options and alternate care," Brian said."They also offer limited counseling and support to employees who experience extra stress as a result of managing family and work during the long summer vacation."• Oblige them. "At VAI, many of our team members have extended family in various countries around the world," said CEO Bob Vormittag. "When it comes to vacation, people often take weeks at a time to travel overseas to see family."How to accommodate? The software firm makes covering for absences a culture cog. "Our team approach here allows them to unplug and truly enjoy their time away," Vormittag said, with full confidence their colleagues are minding the store.

Creighton Abrams wanted to see the whole battlefield.
So he directed his tank regiment while sticking out of his turret.
"Get down!" he was warned.
The Army colonel refused and was never even wounded.
What he did was win — especially on D-Day and the Battle of the Bulge during World War II.
A quarter-century later he was a crucial cog in the buildup and drawdown of American forces in Vietnam and to overseeing the creation of the all-volunteer Army.
Abrams (1914-74) grew up in rural Agawam, Mass., the son of a railroad mechanic and a mother who cared for three children in the close-knit family.

Everyone in the area was poor, but this didn't mean much until Abrams received a scholarship to Brown University in his senior year of high school, based on his athletic and academic record. The family had to turn it down because it couldn't afford the books.
A Turn To The Army
He took the West Point test, passing with soaring marks and then borrowed $300 for his uniform and expenses before entering in 1932.

The Army that Abrams joined as a horse cavalry platoon commander in 1936 was "small, scattered, ill-equipped, antiquated and uncertain about the future," Lewis Sorley, author of "Thunderbolt: General Creighton Abrams and the Army of His Times," told IBD. "Its 155,000 men made it 17th in size among the armies of the world, behind those of nations such as Romania and Yugoslavia."
Still, Abrams saw the future: tanks. He transferred to them even while the Army's chief of cavalry ridiculed the idea that "an untried machine can displace the proved and tried horse."
By July 1942, with America in the thick of World War II, Abrams was on a roll. He took command of the 3rd Battalion, 37th Armored Regiment, and soon earned a reputation as a tactical experimenter.

"Two keys to his later success were that he was innovative and a lifelong learner," said Gregory Padgett, professor of history at Eckerd College in St. Petersburg, Fla. "But while he was aggressive, he also carefully prepared, which is sometimes an unusual balance in the military. That combination allowed him to overcome extraordinary challenges on the European battlefield."

After landing in Normandy on D-Day, June 6, 1944, Abrams spearheaded the attack, showing he had great battlefield intuition. He sensed when to take risks and where to go to surprise the enemy, his men recalled.
Abrams' outfit got so far ahead of the rest of the 4th Armored Division in September 1944 that it spent four days behind enemy lines, knocking out dozens of tanks and killing 2,000 German soldiers.

On Sept. 19, the American tanks ran into a massive concentration of German armor at Arracourt, France. Abrams gave the order — charge — and in four days the 37th destroyed 55 of the enemy machines while losing just 14.
It was one of the greatest tank-vs.-tank battles of the war, for which Abrams was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross.

This was despite U.S. tanks having inadequate numbers, armor and guns. The Americans offset the disadvantages with a turret that could turn faster and with training that emphasized lightning mobility bull's-eye shots.
Cheers

The Stars & Stripes newspaper praised Abrams for being "cherished by his people because he respected them for what they did. He never seemed to use the force of his rank as a weapon of command. That was the style of his greatness beyond his immense ability as a military man."
Abrams' style offers a lesson for anyone in business: People will follow someone who leads from the front and walks the talk.

In early December 1944, the Germans launched the Battle of the Bulge. Suddenly, the 101st Airborne Division was surrounded by superior German forces at Bastogne, Belgium. The call went out to the 4th Armored to rush 120 miles to break through.
The 37th Tank and 53rd Armored Infantry battalions fought their way there. Then the day after Christmas, Abrams directed the assault that relieved the 101st. For this he received his second DSC.
"It was a daring thing and well done, the most brilliant operation we have thus far performed," Gen. George Patton wrote in his diary.
He later said, "I'm supposed to be the best tank commander in the Army, but I have one peer—Abrams is the world champion."
On Target
One officer estimated that by war's end Abrams' tank, named Thunderbolt, had destroyed more German tanks than any other.
Another lesson from Abrams' WWII experience: Aggressiveness and innovation can make up for being the smaller player.
After the war ended in 1945, Abrams taught tactics at the Armor School at Fort Knox, Ky. He then oversaw tank units in Europe and was a corps chief of staff in Korea following the 1953 armistice.

By 1967, Abrams was a four-star general and deputy to William Westmoreland, head of U.S. forces in Vietnam. The American search-and-destroy tactics weren't producing progress in the war, so a year later President Lyndon Johnson gave Abrams the top spot.
"The tactics changed within 15 minutes of Abrams taking command," said Fred Weyand, the general who became Abrams' second in command in 1970.
Sorley said Abrams' new approach was based on his grasp of the war, that South Vietnam's army needed a huge upgrade to break the Viet Cong's hold over the rural population.
By early 1969, American troops peaked at 543,000 in Vietnam, and the new president, Richard Nixon, ordered the drawdown. Abrams had the task of shifting war responsibility to local forces.

All the while, students at American college campus began protesting against the fighting. When one commander complained that Armed Forces Radio was providing too much coverage of anti-war activities at home, Abrams responded: "We should never protect our men from the truth, because the very system of government for which they fight and sacrifice has its basic strength in its citizenry knowing the facts. It is our job to persevere in the atmosphere of the facts."
A lesson from Abrams' Vietnam experience: Sometimes we need to make the best of a situation, regardless of how it was created.

The strengthening of the South Vietnamese army worked well enough that it repelled a full-scale North Vietnamese invasion in the spring of 1972. Vietnamization, as the shift was called, proceeded fast, with only 25,000 American soldiers left when the Paris Peace Accords were signed in January 1973.
By then, Abrams had left Saigon to become the Army's chief of staff. Now he was running another transition: to an all-volunteer force.

"Abrams returned from five long years in Vietnam to head an Army that was widely viewed as dispirited and in need of reform," Sorley said. "His reputation for integrity and competence, and the universal respect and affection for him that ran through the Army's ranks, were in themselves important parts of dealing with the manifold problems of the day."
New Military
The process of shedding the draft resulted in the all-volunteer Army in 1973. The professional soldiers would turn America's military into the sharpest in history.
Abrams was still running the Army when he died of lung cancer just shy of his 60th birthday.

Six years later, in February 1980, the M1 Abrams tank, which he had helped nurture, began rolling off production lines.Creighton Abrams wanted to see the whole battlefield.So he directed his tank regiment while sticking out of his turret."Get down!" he was warned.The Army colonel refused and was never even wounded.What he did was win — especially on D-Day and the Battle of the Bulge during World War II.A quarter-century later he was a crucial cog in the buildup and drawdown of American forces in Vietnam and to overseeing the creation of the all-volunteer Army.Abrams (1914-74) grew up in rural Agawam, Mass., the son of a railroad mechanic and a mother who cared for three children in the close-knit family.Everyone in the area was poor, but this didn't mean much until Abrams received a scholarship to Brown University in his senior year of high school, based on his athletic and academic record. Leadership: Europe's outpouring of grief over the death of Vaclav Havel, hero of Czechoslovakia's great Velvet Revolution, says much about its longing for more like him. His honesty and courage liberated Europe.

Some 75,000 Czechs bearing roses and candles lined up in Wenceslas Square beginning Sunday, as they once did in 1989, to pay tribute to one of the greatest freedom fighters of the 20th century. Havel died Sunday at age 75 after liberating his country, leading his nation as president from 1989-2003, and voicing his moral authority to scourge lingering tyrants in Cuba, Burma and China.

Havel, a playwright whose health had been weakened by years spent in communist dungeons, was an unlikely and yet perfect leader for leading Eastern Europe's liberation from communism. He unshackled Europe with the only weapon in his arsenal — words, which he animated and empowered by expressing them truthfully.

In the former Czechoslovakia, the nightmare of communism imposed after World War II was employed with a Nazi-like oppressive intensity, leaving a bleak society whose citizens got by on lies, collaboration, mediocrity and ratlike survival ethics.

"We live in a contaminated moral environment. We fell morally ill because we became used to saying something different from what we thought. We learned not to believe in anything, to ignore each other, to care only about ourselves. Concepts such as love, friendship, compassion, humility, or forgiveness lost their depth and dimensions. ... Only a few of us were able to cry out loud that the powers that be should not be all-powerful," Havel told his nation after being elected the first president of the restored democracy in December 1989.

Condemned from birth as a "bourgeois element," Havel was always an outsider who could never become a "new communist man" or a cog in the machine of "progress." Denied admission to university, denied jobs, denied permission to leave the country, spied on by secret police and refused liberty in prison beginning in 1979, he managed to free his country by standing up for freedom against all odds.

It was an incredible dream then — because right up until the end, no one believed communism would ever fall. Havel's Velvet Revolution changed that, as first a few thousand, and then a few hundred thousand flooded the streets calling for the regime's end — and the move spread like wildfire through Europe and eventually hit the gates of Moscow.
Havel's peaceful revolution, unlike almost any other, left all oppressive regimes — to this very day — uncertain about their self-declared permanence.

All the same, the sorry imitations now seen in Egypt and Libya and other places leave people skeptical. That's because they aren't animated by the classical concepts of liberty and human rights that Havel's truth was.

First, his plays pointed out the rampant dishonesty, collaboration and conformity of society under communism and enraged the regime for that alone. Then in 1976, motivated by the regime's arrest of a psychedelic rock band called "Plastic People of the Universe," he initiated the first call for political freedom through his Charter 77, a manifesto for liberty on classical principles. He got 242 others to sign it — only a few years after Soviet tanks crushed Czechoslovakia's freedom fighters in a bloody 1968 invasion.
And yet, Havel himself said that standing up for freedom was the only choice.

"Humanity will pay the price for communism until such a time as we learn to stand up to it with all political responsibility and decisiveness," he said, encouraging a group of Cuban civil society organizers in 2006.

Havel not only articulated the corrosive effect of communism on the human soul as few others did, he also warned the West to defend its liberties and free markets.Leadership: Europe's outpouring of grief over the death of Vaclav Havel, hero of Czechoslovakia's great Velvet Revolution, says much about its longing for more like him. Pushing his agenda for higher taxes on "the rich," President Obama kicked off his Dec. 6 speech in Kansas by saying his Kansas grandparents "shared the optimism of a nation that triumphed over the Great Depression." In fact, the 1929 stock market crash turned into the long-running Great Depression because the counterproductive soak-the-rich policies of the federal government hadn't "triumphed"…
"We're a small cog in the overall semiconductor industry. But we're an essential cog," said Richard Hill, chief executive of Novellus Systems (NVLS), in a recent interview.
The San Jose, Calif.-based company makes thin film deposition systems and other technology used in making chips that go into PCs and other computing devices.
Its customers are leading chipmakers, such as Intel (INTC), Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM).
"You heard the slogan, 'Intel Inside.' We're inside Intel," Hill said.

In the outside world, Novellus, which posted $1.3 billion in revenue in 2010, is being talked about as a potential takeover target in the wake of Applied Material's (AMAT) $5 billion bid to buy Varian Semiconductor Equipment (VSEA), which amounts to a huge premium.
Applied Material, with $9.5 billion in revenue last year, is the No. 1 semiconductor equipment firm in its field.

Tokyo Electron, the second largest, may be looking to make an acquisition to keep up with its bigger rival, analysts say. Novellus is viewed as a leading contender. Lam Research (LRCX) also is seen as a potential buyer in the consolidating space.
Access To Technology

"It's a natural fit in one sense," said analyst Ben Pang of Caris & Co., noting that Novellus would give Tokyo Electron access to its chemical vapor deposition, or CVD, technology, something it doesn't have a lot of now.
"CVD is still the core of (Novellus); it's the biggest growth lever for them," he said.
Novellus' CEO says the company never comments on rumors.
"We work with Lam and Tokyo Electron to solve customer needs," he said. "They have etch technology. We have deposition technology. The combination of those two technologies is critical."
Hill added that "just because I'm out to dinner" with execs from either firm doesn't mean they are talking mergers.

"We're not out hawking the company. We're a public company. Anybody who wants to buy the shares is free to buy the shares," he said. "Nobody in the company is trying to thwart it or make it happen. If it makes sense from a business sense and shareholder value, management always acts in the interests of the shareholders."
Novellus' shareholder-friendly stock buyback program "indicates the company's openness to a reasonable acquisition proposal," wrote Credit Suisse analysts in a note to clients.

They listed a number of reasons Novellus would be a good buyout pick: its low-cost debt, low earnings multiple, cash-rich balance sheet, technology to help deal with upcoming changes in chip manufacturing and senior management approaching retirement age.

Hill, 59, has been CEO for 18 years. He's seen chip cycles come and go. He likens today's growth cycle to the long one from the mid-90s to early 2000s. That cycle was marked by multiple drivers, not least of which was the worldwide rollout of the Internet.
Hill thinks the current cycle could also last about seven years, with five more to go.
As the cyclical chip industry goes, so goes Novellus and other companies that provide the building blocks for chips.

The Internet is "gentrifying," Hill says, with the advent of 3G and 4G, streaming video, social media and the storage cloud. All the new technologies need a very broad bandwidth pipe and more demand for high-performing chips, he says.
Reports of a slowdown in PC shipments are overblown, he says, particularly if you consider China, whose consumers are buying not only PCs but also smartphones, TVs and other products needing chips.
"People underestimate the significance of China in worldwide growth of PC technology," Hill said. "And I don't expect (that significant growth) to change anytime soon."
Greater China was the source of 40% of Novellus' first-quarter revenue vs. 34% from the U.S. Total revenue in the quarter jumped 49.6% vs. the prior year to $413.2 million.
Management noted that PC-related sales are being helped by a corporate "refresh cycle."
Profit in the quarter rose 121% over last year to $1.04 a share. Analysts tracked by Thomson Reuters expect per-share profit to grow 18% for the full year, to $3.57 a share, and go up 3% in 2012.

Only a few analysts have made forecasts for 2013, and their outlook is for a double-dip drop. But Pang says a lot of it will depend on how the economy shapes up and the "capital intensity" of the chip industry then.
Industry Consolidation
The chip industry is consolidating and, as the number of companies shrinks, growth in demand becomes more "real," closely tied to capacity, Pang says.
"You don't have much overcapacity being built in the industry right now," he said.
Meanwhile, the industry is benefiting from growth in smartphones and tablets.
Last year, capital spending in the sector grew over 100%, and he says it'll be up 10% to 20% this year.

Novellus is a leader in a key area of chipmaking known as copper processing. That's important because most new chip factories are transitioning from aluminum wiring to copper as the primary conductive material in chip devices. Copper has lower electrical resistance and performance and cost advantages.
In terms of copper processing, "Novellus is a market-share-gain story," Pang said. In copper applications, Novellus beats Applied Material, he says.

It's also gaining share in the CVD market, though Applied Material still leads Novellus. Pang puts Novellus' share of the CVD market at 45% to Applied's 55%."We're a small cog in the overall semiconductor industry. But we're an essential cog," said Richard Hill, chief executive of Novellus Systems (NVLS), in a recent interview.The San Jose, Calif.-based company makes thin film deposition systems and other technology used in making chips that go into PCs and other computing devices.Its customers are leading chipmakers, such as Intel (INTC), Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM)."You heard the slogan, 'Intel Inside.' That cycle was marked by multiple drivers, not least of which was the worldwide rollout of the Internet.Hill thinks the current cycle could also last about seven years, with five more to go.As the cyclical chip industry goes, so goes Novellus and other companies that provide the building blocks for chips.The Internet is "gentrifying," Hill says, with the advent of 3G and 4G, streaming video, social media and the storage cloud. All the new technologies need a very broad bandwidth pipe and more demand for high-performing chips, he says.Reports of a slowdown in PC shipments are overblown, he says, particularly if you consider China, whose consumers are buying not only PCs but also smartphones, TVs and other products needing chips."People underestimate the significance of China in worldwide growth of PC technology," Hill said. "And I don't expect (that significant growth) to change anytime soon."Greater China was the source of 40% of Novellus' first-quarter revenue vs. 34% from the U.S. Total revenue in the quarter jumped 49.6% vs. the prior year to $413.2 million.Management noted that PC-related sales are being helped by a corporate "refresh cycle."Profit in the quarter rose 121% over last year to $1.04 a share. Analysts tracked by Thomson Reuters expect per-share profit to grow 18% for the full year, to $3.57 a share, and go up 3% in 2012.Only a few analysts have made forecasts for 2013, and their outlook is for a double-dip drop. But Pang says a lot of it will depend on how the economy shapes up and the "capital intensity" of the chip industry then.Industry ConsolidationThe chip industry is consolidating and, as the number of companies shrinks, growth in demand becomes more "real," closely tied to capacity, Pang says."You don't have much overcapacity being built in the industry right now," he said.Meanwhile, the industry is benefiting from growth in smartphones and tablets.Last year, capital spending in the sector grew over 100%, and he says it'll be up 10% to 20% this year.Novellus is a leader in a key area of chipmaking known as copper processing. That's important because most new chip factories are transitioning from aluminum wiring to copper as the primary conductive material in chip devices. Copper has lower electrical resistance and performance and cost advantages.In terms of copper processing, "Novellus is a market-share-gain story," Pang said. In copper applications, Novellus beats Applied Material, he says.It's also gaining share in the CVD market, though Applied Material still leads Novellus. Pang puts Novellus' share of the CVD market at 45% to Applied's 55%.

"The Lord of the Rings" looked like it would be a dud. It was 1954, and the publisher wasn't bullish about selling even 3,500 copies of the book's first of three volumes. Why? The opus would turn into a 1,200-page fantasy, a passe genre, with appendixes of character genealogies and invented languages that would be simply too complex for readers.…

Stocks surged to big gains Thursday, putting the market's rally back on track. The tech-rich Nasdaq composite jumped 1.9%. The Dow industrials climbed 1.7%. The S&P 500 surged 1.9% while the energy-laden NYSE composite led with a 2.1% gain. Nasdaq volume nudged slightly lower, off 0.3%. NYSE volume eased 6%. However, scores of leading stocks rallied in heavier volume, a…

Emmitt Smith ran to the peak of the National Football League.He amassed rushing records for yards (18,355), touchdowns (164) and 100-yard games (78).He was a cog on three NFL title teams with the Dallas Cowboys.He won league and Super Bowl Most Valuable Player trophies.He was first-team All-Pro four times. And after a 15-year career, he entered the Pro Football Hall of Fame.Not bad for a running back who stood just 5 feet 9 inches and had to put up with naysayers early on the football field.Even in college, people contended he wasn't big enough or strong enough or fast enough.He Ignored Them"You will always have critics, no matter who you are," Smith, 42, told IBD. "If you're successful, people are either patting you on the back or tearing you down."If you start worrying about what people are saying — especially if it's not true — you'll lose your focus. You need to concentrate on what you hope to accomplish, not on what people are saying. They don't determine your outcome; they're not in control of what you do."From childhood, Smith was determined to make it into the NFL. In his new memoir, "Game On," he writes about how he had visions of an NFL career, imagining himself as Tony Dorsett or Walter Payton scoring touchdowns.To be successful, he told IBD, "you have to have a dream or a vision."And you must grasp how to progress, he added: "It's one thing to sit on the sofa or on the sideline and say 'I like this' or 'I want to have that,' but without understanding what it takes to achieve it, it won't happen. A lot of time in our society, people do a lot of coveting without taking the necessary steps to (make it happen)."Smith's steps involved spending marathon hours practicing football and lifting weights. "It takes a lot of preparation," he said.He definitely had that, said Michael Irvin, who played with Smith in Dallas, also reached the Hall of Fame and now is an analyst at NFL Network: "Emmitt was always prepared. You never had to worry about him. He was always on time and ready to play."Before Emmitt was too small, he was plenty big enough. He was so stout as a youngster in Florida, he was moved up a grade to play with older boys in his peewee league.Big PlansBecause the older boys were bulkier, Emmitt wasn't getting the playing time he hungered for.Instead of sulking on the sideline, he studied every position and prepared to play each spot — on offense and defense — so he could get additional time on the field."I use the context of sports as a metaphor for business," he said. "You have to understand every aspect of your business, whether it's warehousing, marketing, financing, accounts receivable, product ordering. The more you understand, the better you'll be able to run it."A lot of people come up with great ideas, great concepts, but don't follow up with due diligence, put it all in a business plan, get financing and then execute the plan."Even if you do all that, every business experiences growing pains. If you are not prepared for those changes it's all for nothing."The Long ViewEven in his playing days he planned for a career in real estate and construction. He networked with mentors, particularly former Cowboys quarterback Roger Staubach, who provided advice and introductions.Smith also took classes in real estate finance and law as well as related subjects. He wanted to know what questions to ask."If you're going to do something, you need to do it full throttle," he said. "If I was going to go into real estate, I had to understand the lingo. There is a specific language, and I had to understand it so I could communicate properly about financing, acreage."So, yes, I had to go back to school, because understanding and being able to communicate were really important to me."He leapt into real estate soon after retiring from football. And last year in the teeth of the housing flop he started two companies, EJ Smith Construction in Dallas and ESmith Legacy in Baltimore.Approaching life "full throttle" is how Smith approached football."There's a saying in Vegas that scared money can't make money," he said. "You can't play in a major league ballpark if you play afraid (of being injured). You have to take that leap of faith. If you want to get to that next level and stay at that next level, fear cannot be part of your repertoire."Working in his garage, Bill Gates wasn't worried about whether his operating system was going to work. But it did, and it changed the world. If the Wright brothers were afraid, we wouldn't have the airline industry. Fear is something that can help you find success, but you can't let it dominate you."When he entered the league, Smith emphasized reality rather than 100-yard games or touchdowns right away."Setting meaningful goals is absolutely critical," he said. "Anyone can set pie-in-the-sky goals, but I wasn't interested in that. When I got into the league, my first goal was just to average 4 yards a carry."For the record, Irvin remembers things a little differently."In his rookie year (of 1990) he said to me, 'I'm going to be the all-time leading rusher and we're going to win Super Bowls.' I told him, 'You're crazy, man. You don't know what you're saying.' But he was right."Perhaps that's because Smith always wanted more."I've seen it happen from a sports standpoint," he said. "Some guys with big aspirations come into the league, make an enormous amount of money, more than they've ever had, and they're suddenly content."But you can't be satisfied. You have to create new goals, new challenges. It's the same in business. What do you do after you open up? How do you sustain it? You grow your business to $2 million. How do you get to $3 million? You have to stay hungry. That's what keeps you on your toes."Something else that drove him was his desire to leave a positive legacy — not just in terms of statistics, but also moral fiber.In 2003, the Cowboys released him after his 13 seasons wearing the blue star on his helmet.He quickly signed a two-year contract with the Arizona Cardinals. He could easily have coasted, especially after he was injured early in the 2003 campaign — against Dallas. His coach wanted to place him on injured reserve, which would have ended that first season for Smith, but the star refused.He rehabilitated his banged-up shoulder and returned for the last month of the season. He wanted to honor his commitment.He worked so hard in the off-season and training camp, he was named — at age 35 — a starter as a running back. He came through with nine touchdowns and just under 1,000 yards rushing.Healthy OutlookWhy come back that year and risk another injury?"I did not want to go out on a sour note," Smith said. "I wanted to honor my contract and show my younger teammates, who looked up to me, how it should be done. Coming from Dallas, a winning organization, to Arizona, a not-so-winning organization, I wanted to give them a glimpse of how we did it in Dallas, to give them a glimpse of how we carried ourselves and prepared ourselves. To me, all that is, is passing the baton to help others. Oftentimes I hear kids say they want to be like me. I tell them I don't want you to be like me. I want you to be better than me."Smith the entertainer was all business on the football field. Take the time he exploded past the Atlanta Falcons on a touchdown run."It was like he bounced off 20 bodies and still kept running," recalled Irvin. "When we got to the sideline I sat down next to him and said, 'That's the most spectacular touchdown run I've ever seen.' You know what he said to me? 'Why were you looking? You should have been blocking.'"
5:15 p.m. Update: After-hours action was calm Friday with no notable economic news or companies reporting.
Monday, however, will be busy. Over 100 companies are scheduled to release earnings, and few have specified when.

The most notable stocks that will release their quarterly results before the market opens include American Public Education (APEI), Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation (COG), Constellation Energy Group (CEG) and MedAssets (MDAS). Several top-rated companies are set to release results after Monday's close.

No U.S. economic news is scheduled before the market opens. The first two items on the day's docket are comments from Janet Yellen, San Francisco Fed President, at 10:30 a.m. EST, followed by Fed Chief Ben Bernanke at 11 a.m. EST.
U.S. Stocks Rally To Close Higher
BY PATRICK CAIN
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed modestly higher Friday after bouncing from an afternoon slide.
The Dow, Nasdaq rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 0.2%. The NYSE composite finished fractionally higher. Volume rose, according to preliminary readings.
Indexes brushed off the Fed's discount rate increase.

China Agritech (CAGC), Cree (CREE) and WebMD (WBMD) made new highs. WebMD found support at its 50-day line. NetGear (NTGR) gained 2%. The high-volume advance set the stock up into a possible short-stroke pattern. The potential buy point on this rare formation is 25.32.
On the downside, DG FastChannel (DGIT) dove 8% in fast trade. The stock snapped its eight-session up streak. BWS Financial downgraded the stock to buy from strong buy.
HMS Holdings (HMSY) dropped 4%. The move put it back below its 50-day line. Volume was three times its normal pace as the company reported earnings.
U.S. Stocks Look To Continue Win Streak
BY PATRICK CAIN
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks started to slip in midafternoon trade as volume stayed slightly higher.
The Dow and Nasdaq gained 0.1% each. The S&P 500 and NYSE composite rose 0.2%. The Philadelphia semiconductor index was up 0.4%  in line for a sixth straight gain.

Vistaprint (VPRT) added 4% and passed a possible low-handle buy point of 57.97. The market, however, remains in correction, and all buys are off the table. Vistaprint's move was coming in average volume. That may make this just a continuation of building the stock's right side and not a handle. That would be better, as low handles are faulty.

On the downside, Micrus Endovascular (MEND) reversed and dived 6%. The stock was up 10 of the past 11 sessions and made gains in the last seven straight. Volume was huge. The developer, manufacturer and marketer of both implantable and disposable medical devices used in the treatment of cerebral vascular diseases is 46% above its cup-with-handle base. It broke out during the week of Dec. 4.

Trina Solar (TSL) fell 5%. The Chinese solar firm gapped below its 50-day moving average after finishing above it for three straight days. Solar stocks are being dragged down after rival First Solar beat views but said industry supply could exceed demand in the second half of 2010.

Trina is in its sixth week of an ugly-looking base. The left side of the cup came during two weeks of big losses in huge volume. Such a quick shaping of any side of a base is not ideal. The high volume is also problematic, as the accumulation-distribution count is at -1.
U.S. Stocks Strain To Hold Advances
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
2:15 p.m. Update: Market gains seeped lower, leaving indexes with scant advances at midafternoon.
The NYSE composite and Dow clutched 0.1% advances. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 held 0.2% gains. Volume remained sharply higher on the NYSE and modestly higher on the Nasdaq.

Small caps outran the general market, with the S&P 600 cruising with a 0.5% gain. Clearwater Paper (CLW) was that index's biggest gainer. It jumped 12% in more than six times average volume, but it still remained in the lower half of the stock's range for the week after a 17% sell-off Thursday.
Alliance Data Systems  (ADS) climbed 3%, leaving it up 6% so far this week and marking its first possible weekly gain after a five-week decline.

On the downside, Canadian Solar (CSIQ) took a 15% wallop. The solar panel maker raised its guidance for Q4 shipments, but said higher processing costs and lower yields caused by "certain defective production equipment" would lower margins to the midteens, down from prior guidance for the high teens.
U.S. Stocks Stake Out High ground, NYSE Volume Surges
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks held near session highs as traders picked up the pace after midday.

Among the major indexes, the S&P 500 led, up 0.4%. Oil and gas field equipment maker Smith International (SII) topped the S&P 500's advancers, up 13% on news reports of a possible buyout by Schlumberger (SLB). Schlumberger shares dropped 3%
The NYSE and Nasdaq composites each held 0.2% gains. The Dow advanced 0.3%.
Volume was up about 4% on the Nasdaq, and tracked more than 40% higher on the NYSE.
Among tech stocks, Quickbooks maker Intuit (INTU) vaulted 9% in huge trade and Juniper Networks (JNPR), a telecom infrastructure specialist, grabbed a 4% gain.

Transportation issues led the market, with the Dow transports running 1.6% in the black as FedEx (FDX) and JetBlue Airways (JBLU) both posted 3% advances. Boeing (BA) pressed forward 2% in strong trade.
China Agritech (CAGC) soared 8% in heavy action, breaking to a new high and putting the stock ahead 28% so far for the week.
On the downside, Spain-based IT firm Telvent (TLVT) imploded 12% in frenzied selling after reporting flat Q4 EPS, yet still 2% above analyst consensus views. Sales slipped 12%.
U.S. Stocks Turn Higher; Investors Shrug Off Rate Hike
BY JONAH KERI

12:15 p.m. Update: U.S. markets turned slightly higher Friday, as investors looked past the Federal Reserve's decision to raise its discount lending rate for banks and also digested a tame reading on consumer inflation.

The S&P 500 rose 0.3%, the Dow 0.2% and the Nasdaq 0.1%. The NYSE composite was trading flat. Volume was mixed, rising 42% on the NYSE and falling 2% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Thursday.

China Agritech (CAGC) rose 4% in nearly twice its normal trade. Like many top Chinese stocks, China Agritech fell hard after China's government ordered banks to curb lending, in an effort to cool a potentially overheating economy. But the Chinese fertilizer company has staged a strong rebound, and now sits near a 52-week high.

Sirona Dental Systems (SIRO) advanced 2% in brisk volume. The maker of high-tech dental equipment rebounded above its 50-day moving average on a bullish quarterly earnings report last week. The stock hit a new high Tuesday, pulled back after a secondary stock offering, and is now approaching its peak again.
Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) gained 3% in above-average turnover. The Israeli drugmaker has posted accelerating sales and earnings growth in the past two quarters.
U.S. Stocks Pare Losses; Quiet Day For Leaders
BY JONAH KERI
11:15 a.m. Update: The major indexes pared early losses Friday, as leading stocks showed little reaction to the Federal Reserve's decision to raise its discount lending rate for banks.
The NYSE composite gave up 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.2%. The S&P 500 and Dow slipped 0.1% each. Volume remained higher across the board.

ATP Oil & Gas (ATPG) slid 3% in twice its usual turnover. The oil and gas natural gas exploration and production firm's stock found support at its 50-day moving average. The company will report quarterly results on March 4.
JDA Software (JDAS) dipped 2% in rapid volume. The maker of demand and supply chain and business process management software remains in an uptrend. It sits just 4% off its 52-week high.
On the upside, Ezcorp (EZPW) rose 2% in four times its normal trade. The payday lending company's stock notched an all-time high. It carries a highest possible 99 in Composite Rating.
Stocks Open Lower On Rate Hike Concerns
BY JONAH KERI
10:15 a.m. Update: The major indexes fell at the opening bell Friday, as investors wrestled with the Federal Reserve's decision to raise the discount rate.
The S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq fell 0.5% each. The NYSE composite lost 0.8%. Volume swelled across the board.

Trina Solar (TSL) plunged 7% in heavy volume. The maker of solar modules topped fourth-quarter sales and earnings estimates. But it cut its profit margin forecast, sending shares sharply lower at the open.
Home Inns & Hotels (HMIN) sank 3% in brisk trade. The Chinese hotel operator flashed multiple down days in heavy volume as it dropped off its January highs. The stock sits 23% off its 52-week peak.
On the upside, WebMD Health  (WBMD) smashed quarterly revenue and profit estimates. The stock gapped up on the news, surging 5% in rapid turnover and breaking out of a short, flat consolidation.
U.S. Stock Futures Fall On Fed Rate Hike
BY JONAH KERI

9:15 a.m. Update: U.S. markets were poised for a lower start Friday, as the Federal Reserve surprised investors by raising the interest rate it charges banks. S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq 100 futures all traded lower in the pre-market.

The Fed's decision Thursday to raise the discount rate rattled investors, who have grown accustomed to near-zero interest rates. Still, economists see the movie as a sign the U.S. economy is improving.

The Consumer Price Index edged up 0.2% in January, coming in below forecasts of 0.3%. Meanwhile, consumer prices excluding food and energy slid 0.1%, marking the first monthly decline since December 1982.

J.C. Penney (JCP) reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.02 a share, excluding a large pension expense and other charges. Results topped Wall Street views of 82 cents. The department store's chain Q4 revenue of $5.5 billion matched estimates. The stock soared 6% in pre-market trade.

Swiss food giant Nestle reported a steep drop in annual earnings from the prior year, when it benefited from the sale of part of its stake in eye care company Alcon. Organic growth was 4.1%, below the company's own long-term goal of 5% to 6% a year.
March crude oil fell $1.05 to $78.01 a barrel, after the Fed's interest-rate hike sparked a rally in the dollar.
Futures Point To Lower Open
BY VANCE CARIAGA
8:15 a.m. Update: Stock futures signaled a lower open Friday after the Federal Reserve's surprising decision to raise the interest rate it charges banks.
S&P 500 futures fell 6.4 points and were below fair value. Dow futures retreated 39 points, while Nasdaq 100 futures lost 5.75 points.

The Fed on Thursday announced its move to raise the discount rate. The decision came as a shock to investors who have become accustomed to near-zero interest rates  despite the fact that a higher rate is a sign the economy is on the right track.

The Labor Department will release January consumer prices at 8:30 a.m. Economists expect a gain of 0.3% compared with a 0.1% uptick rise the prior month. Excluding volatile food and energy items, CPI is seen rising 0.1%, matching the December reading.

Shares of Dell (DELL) fell more than 6% in the pre-market on disappointing Q4 results. The computer manufacturer posted earnings of 28 cents a share, excluding items. That was a penny above views. Revenue rose 11% to $14.9 billion, also beating expectations. But adjusted gross margin was 17.4%, below the average estimate of 18%, as Dell was hurt by a rise in costs for memory chips and other components.

Elsewhere, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell to 3.80% early Friday from 3.81% late Thursday. The yield on the three-month T-bill climbed to 0.12% from 0.08%. The dollar rose against other major currencies. Gold and oil prices declined.

Overseas, Japan's Nikkei stock average fell 2.1%. In afternoon trading, Britain's FTSE 100 was down 0.07%, Germany's DAX slipped 0.16% and France's CAC-40 gave up 0.27%.5:15 p.m. Update: After-hours action was calm Friday with no notable economic news or companies reporting.Monday, however, will be busy. Still, economists see the movie as a sign the U.S. economy is improving.The Consumer Price Index edged up 0.2% in January, coming in below forecasts of 0.3%. Meanwhile, consumer prices excluding food and energy slid 0.1%, marking the first monthly decline since December 1982.J.C. Penney (JCP) reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.02 a share, excluding a large pension expense and other charges. Results topped Wall Street views of 82 cents. The department store's chain Q4 revenue of $5.5 billion matched estimates. The stock soared 6% in pre-market trade.Swiss food giant Nestle reported a steep drop in annual earnings from the prior year, when it benefited from the sale of part of its stake in eye care company Alcon. Organic growth was 4.1%, below the company's own long-term goal of 5% to 6% a year.March crude oil fell $1.05 to $78.01 a barrel, after the Fed's interest-rate hike sparked a rally in the dollar.Futures Point To Lower OpenBY VANCE CARIAGA8:15 a.m. Update: Stock futures signaled a lower open Friday after the Federal Reserve's surprising decision to raise the interest rate it charges banks.S&P 500 futures fell 6.4 points and were below fair value. Dow futures retreated 39 points, while Nasdaq 100 futures lost 5.75 points.The Fed on Thursday announced its move to raise the discount rate. The decision came as a shock to investors who have become accustomed to near-zero interest rates  despite the fact that a higher rate is a sign the economy is on the right track.The Labor Department will release January consumer prices at 8:30 a.m. Economists expect a gain of 0.3% compared with a 0.1% uptick rise the prior month. Excluding volatile food and energy items, CPI is seen rising 0.1%, matching the December reading.Shares of Dell (DELL) fell more than 6% in the pre-market on disappointing Q4 results. The computer manufacturer posted earnings of 28 cents a share, excluding items. That was a penny above views. Revenue rose 11% to $14.9 billion, also beating expectations. But adjusted gross margin was 17.4%, below the average estimate of 18%, as Dell was hurt by a rise in costs for memory chips and other components.Elsewhere, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell to 3.80% early Friday from 3.81% late Thursday. The yield on the three-month T-bill climbed to 0.12% from 0.08%. The dollar rose against other major currencies. Gold and oil prices declined.Overseas, Japan's Nikkei stock average fell 2.1%. In afternoon trading, Britain's FTSE 100 was down 0.07%, Germany's DAX slipped 0.16% and France's CAC-40 gave up 0.27%.

Tech stocks were set for what could be a breakout bonanza Friday, spearheaded by Amazon.com (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Intel (INTC).  Overall, futures traded in mixed territory after first-quarter GDP data was better-than-expected, while quarterly reports from blue chip energy stocks delivered some disappointments.Nasdaq 100 futures strengthened to 0.5% above fair value, although futures had backed well away from gains posted in extended trade after Thursday's close. Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.2%. S&P 500 futures traded a fraction below fair value.Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) exerted downward force on both the Dow industrials and the S&P 500, slipping 2% after reporting first-quarter results.A big, 1.6% rebound for the Nasdaq on Thursday narrowed the index's loss for the week to 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrials index hauls a 0.6% loss into Friday's session, while the S&P 500 holds a slim 0.1% loss for the week. All three indexes are about 1 % below their 50-day moving averages.Get Free Access To IBD Digital Through April 29

Get premium stock lists, pass or fail stock ratings and more. Start HereThe Nasdaq 100 outpaced Thursday's action by a wide margin, surging 2.1% as Facebook (FB), Amazon, Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) all scored big gains. That left the index down 0.3% for the week through Thursday, after diving as much as 3.3% to a mid-session low on Wednesday.The message — it's a volatile market — is reflected in IBD's current Market Pulse market status indicator.Preliminary first-quarter GDP growth estimates from the Commerce Department were positive, with growth of 2.3% coming in below the fourth-quarter's 2.9% advance, but outpacing economist projections for a slowdown to 2% growth. The closely-watched price inflation number was also better-than-expected, with the GDP Price Index up 2%, below Q4's 2.3% increase and countering expectations for an uptick to 2.4% growth.Consumer spending met expectations for a 1.1% increase, although well below the prior quarters 4% surge.Leading tech names Expedia (EXPE), Amazon, and Intel reported quarterly results late Thursday.Expedia spiked 10.7% after reporting a narrower-than-expected first-quarter loss late Thursday, and a 15% rise in bookings, to $27.2 billion.Amazon hurtled ahead 7%. The e-commerce giant's first-quarter revenue topped analyst expectations, whereas earnings cleared targets by nearly 77%. The company also announced plans to raise the price of its Prime membership to $119, from $99. Chief Executive Jeff Bezos reported last week that Prime members numbered more than 100 million, worldwide. Amazon's premarket advance set the IBD Leaderboard stock for a starting bell breakout above a 1617.64 buy point in a six-week cup base. There is also an earlier, alternate entry at 1568.62.  The base is a very late-stage pattern. Premarket moves often do not carry over into regular trade.Intel stormed ahead 5.3%, seizing an easy early lead among Dow Jones stocks. A strong first-quarter profit and sales beat, and raised full-year guidance helped dissuade concerns lingering over security weaknesses discovered in its chips early in the year. Intel's premarket gain positioned the stock for a gap-up breakout at the open above a 53.88 buy point in a flat base. Premarket moves often do not carry over into regular trade.Microsoft (MSFT) popped 3.6% higher, as JPMorgan upgraded the stock to overweight, from neutral, and boosted its price target to 110, from 94, after the company's strong fiscal third-quarter report late Thursday. The stock ended Thursday 3.3% below a 97.24 buy point in a flat base.IBD 50 listing SVB Financial Group (SIVB) rattled off a 5% premarket gain following a solid Q1 report late Thursday. The stock finished Thursday less than 6% below a 271.89 buy point in a cup base.Exxon shares fell nearly 4% after reporting first-quarter earnigns stopped one penny short of analyst targets. Chevron was up 0.8% just ahead of the open, after its first quarter earnigns topped expectations by a wide margin, but revenue growth disappointed.Phillips 66 (PSX) and Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) also reported, with TransCanada (TRP) set to report.ConocoPhillips (COP) set expectations for other oil producers high, after crushing first-quarter performance expectations in its report on Thursday.Crude oil prices traded down 0.2% early Friday, with U.S. benchmark crude just above $68 — down 0.5% for the week, but above 6% higher vs. the March 29 settlement. Baker Hughes (BHGE) delivers its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m. ET.The University of Michigan reports its April consumer sentiment estimates at 10 a.m. ET. YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Stock Market Sends This Message To BearsThis Payment Giant Breaks Out On Earnings As Peers Make Bullish Moves5 Reasons You Probably Shouldn't Buy This Hot StockBaidu Quarterly Earnings Beat Expectations, IQiyi Shares Fall

The left's crusade against Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt should be seen for what it is — a witch hunt. We don't need any more conservatives hanged by leftists who major in criminalizing political differences and minor in slander.How dare a Republican president appoint an environmental heretic to head an administrative agency the left views as its sole, separate and absolute property? This agency exists to serve the deep state — the entrenched federal government bureaucracy that is tailor-made to advance the left's agenda and operate above accountability.This conspiratorially organized assault against Pruitt is precisely what Barack Obama and his friends mean by community organizing. It is vicious, relentless street fighting aimed at discrediting Pruitt and taking him down because he is one of the rare administrative officials who won't put politics above the law and will stand up to those who do.The left — always projecting its own malicious practices onto its political opponents — is framing this as its benign campaign to protect the rule of law. Leftists claim that it is Pruitt, appointed by Dr. Donald Evil himself, who is imposing his political agenda. These Alinskyites understand the impact of words and the force of propaganda. Anyone who doesn't swallow whole their radical assumptions on the environment is a menace, especially one who is in a position to make a policy difference.Leftist activists and their media co-pilots are hellbent on disgracing Pruitt and destroying his reputation to effect his removal, so they are throwing all kinds of phony scandals against the wall of public opinion to pressure the White House to give them Pruitt's head.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe energy they are expending on this should tell you how important progressives view unelected, unaccountable administrative agencies in implementing their draconian regulations, which have been choking our individual liberties and wreaking havoc on our economy.The left is blowing a lot of smoke about alleged improprieties with Pruitt's travel expenses. Thank goodness media conservatives, whose very existence leftists lament every day, are on the case. The Wall Street Journal's Kimberley Strassel, in a series of tweets, dismantled this bogus charge simply by comparing Pruitt's travel and security costs with those of his predecessors, whose similar expenses dwarf Pruitt's. And when you add the disturbing factor that Pruitt has been the target of death threats, which have required greater security measures, the contrast between Pruitt's expenses and those of his dutifully liberal forerunners is even more pronounced.There is also the earth-shattering matter of the alleged sweetheart deal Pruitt was given on a condo lease, a transaction that was reviewed and found proper by the EPA's ethics office, which is hardly staffed by Trump supporters.Leftists don't care a whit about these nonissues; they are just using them as cudgels to thwart the democratic process — the legitimate effort of our duly elected president to appoint people who will not advance radical policies by being lawless agents. No matter how desperately leftists want to brand Pruitt as a renegade activist, he is just a cog in the wheel of their activism or, in some cases, the driver who is going to put their environmental vehicle in reverse and slam his foot on the pedal.The left has bullied its way into imposing administrative regulations that are disastrous for business and onerous for individuals. They aren't just horrible in substance; they're also terrible in process. The Obama administration shamelessly thwarted the rule of law and exceeded its authority in issuing many of these regulations.Under Pruitt's leadership, the EPA has eliminated regulations gratuitously detrimental to the coal industry that Obama crafted to achieve his stated agenda of bankrupting that industry. Pruitt has determined, in light of recent data, that the current greenhouse gas emissions standards for cars and light trucks for model years 2022-25 are inappropriate and require revision. In announcing his decision, Pruitt said that "Obama's EPA cut the Midterm Evaluation process short with politically charged expediency, made assumptions about the standards that didn't comport with reality, and set the standards too high."That is, Obama's regulations were not only inappropriate based on the data but also issued unlawfully pursuant to a political agenda. You won't hear leftists or their media water carriers complaining about this.In addition to their angst over Pruitt's revision of the fuel emissions standards, which, incidentally, could reduce the price of new cars by as much as $7,000, The Heritage Foundation's Genevieve Wood offers two reasons the left is going after Pruitt — and neither of them has to do with ethics issues. He has led the Trump administration's efforts to dismantle Obama's "expensive and ineffective climate legacy piece by piece." And his EPA is scrapping the transparency-hostile practice of developing regulations based on studies that are kept secret from the public.One thing I appreciate about President Trump is that he is taking action in certain areas that would have been unthinkable to entrenched politicians, many of whom are so used to the inertia of bad policy that they seem to be paralyzed with feelings of futility. The EPA is one of those areas. We are actually seeing concrete results, and it's immensely refreshing.Like many others, I've long said that we can't afford to sleep for one second in our ongoing battles against leftists because they don't. We need to shed some of the defeatism that has crippled the conservative agenda and celebrate the kind of progress we're seeing at the EPA.The left considers Pruitt a hill to die on. So should we.YOU MIGHT ALSO LIKE:The Stunning Statistical Fraud Behind The Global Warming ScareTrump Dismantles Another Obama 'Achievement' — Just One More To GoSchwarzenegger Wants To Sue Oil Companies For Murder? They've Helped Lift Billions Out Of Poverty
